reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you think I missed something in my review feel free to tell me

Hero Defense - Haunted Island
Hero Defense - Haunted Island is a well made tower defense strategy game that has features which make it a pleasure in the TD Genre. I will add a TL;DR at the end

Gameplay
Hero Defense is not an average tower defense game because instead of building towers in a set area for them to just stand and fire at approaching enemies you get 5 mobile towers/heroes to use. Each one of these heroes has a speciality, skill tree, and weapon rune slots to increase their power when defending. The fact you control where your heroes move and have to tactically place and manage them to successfully fend off wave after wave of enemies helps add to how much fun the game can be. Within maps you also have the option to use and build shrines which can boost specific stats, characters, or simply give you a nice boost.

The story is actually pretty stale, nothing new, nothing surprising. More like a large cliché but that isn’t really harmful to the game as a whole.

Graphics/Sounds
The graphics can be unappealing to some, but overall it’s a more dark 3D transilvania look which matches the game pretty nicely. The artwork and design of certain characters helps to match that theme and help add an appeal to the game.

The music is overall ok, but some of the character voices are simply horrible. The main character Jack along with some of the other heroes make me simply wish I could mute them specifically for the entire game.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Mobile towers/heroes
+ Variation between heroes with strength and weaknesses
+ Unlockable runes to boost heroes
+ Skill trees
+ Enjoyable levels and variation
+ Requires tactical placement and preparation beforehand on heroes to beat later levels (require you to use your head)

Cons

**Note since this is an Early Access title Cons and other parts of the review as well are viable to change as the game continues to develop**
- Stale story
- Grind to get runes and gold to be able to advance (this does not apply to everyone as I know some people like a good grind)
- Some of the character voices are horrid
- Graphics unappealing to some

Suggestions
Suggestions I feel would help the game

- More enemy variations
- Preset targeting for heroes (First, Last, Strongest, Weakest) because more than once my heroes ignored the guys at the front and ended up costing me the mission (and hard to remote target if it’s a giant horde and constantly click so they attack front)

Final Thoughts
A fun tower defense game for sure, love the micromanagement and the rune system. Skill trees are a nice touch along with reconstructing the town for different uses. I did not like the story, it was very predictable following cliché after cliché in its plot. As a tower defense game I love the system of having movable towers since it really is a pleasure to have to use an extra bit of thought to properly position your heroes. Even having to decide if you need to build a shrine or move a certain hero somewhere to be more effective and trying to match runes to help the character be better in different scenarios really made the game more enjoyable.

TL;DR
Hero Defense - Haunted Island is a game for its gameplay with different shrines, runes, skill trees, and 5 different heroes to manage and defend against the undead with. A pleasure to see within the TD genre for its type of structure and overall offering a good amount of playtime potential if you like the game and its style.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’ve long been a fan of the tower defense genre. I especially love games within the genre that attempt to be innovative, those that attempt to tell a story rather than just spit out increasingly more difficult levels at you and those that possess a high presentation level with a lot of charm. All three do a good job of summarizing Happy Tuesday’s fantastic Steam debut in Hero Defense: Haunted Island. It’s the type of game that I know that I will not be able to get enough of and will find time to play throughout my reviewing and playing of future games for Steamified. It’s just that damn good. I am thoroughly enjoying to the point of loving what I have played thus far.

One of the great things about Happy Tuesday’s game is that they haven’t stopped working on it since launching it into the Steam Early Access program. There have already been six updates and patches to the game since it launched on January 26 (the morning of January 27 in Australia which is what date Steam provides me so if my dates are slightly off for some of you you’ll understand why). They’ve planned for a two month early access period so we’re coming up to just under two weeks from an estimated launch date.

Without a shadow of a doubt the game’s greatest strength is its customization. You can practically play the game, as the descriptor says, the way you want to play it. Of course, there will be those who are such avid players of the game that they will argue that there is one best way to play the game – maximizing all of a certain skill set combined with what they consider to be the best runes, etc. but those of us who are more willing to play the game without spending a lot of time looking at all of the statistics to prove one theory right or wrong have a lot of different avenues to play. I’m not suggesting for a moment that those who do choose to maximize the game are going about it the wrong way as that can achieve a deeper level of enjoyment from the game and I’m certain that Happy Tuesday are hoping that their game has such avid fans.

Another feature that I like is that you can move your heroes around the map to put them into the position that you believe is the most productive. This certainly has a massive impact on the employed strategies. If your enemies move too fast then positioning your heroes at the start of the map can be disastrous because by the time that you react it can be a case of too little too late. However, if your enemies are slow and strong positioning far from the beginning can have the opposite effect – you don’t kill them before they get to the end of their path.

There are five heroes in the game. You begin with Jack Sanders who is a vampire slayer and then you unlock Barrows who is a grisly old gravedigger who has lost his poor wife. Barrows is best against skeletons. The next hero that you’re introduced to is the charming Samantha “Sam” Hain whose a precious little pumpkin thrower and zombie killer extraordinaire. The fourth hero is Jane Doe whose brain was used to create a Frankenstein’s monster. The final unlockable hero is Wylde Halfblood who is half-man and half-wolf so your werewolf character which is pretty cool.

Another thing that I very much enjoyed was the fact that the next level isn’t just given to you upon completion of the last. You have to meet certain criteria to unlock many of the zones in the game. What this means is that you need to unlock a certain amount of stars before advancing. You gain stars by completing levels – one star per successful level completion. For example, the first time that you complete a level you will be awarded a single star for that level. The second time you complete the level you will receive a second star and so on and so forth. This is a very good way of level and area progression.

Speaking of progression each character progresses similarly to how they would in many RPGs. As each character levels up you unlock skill points which you can utilize on a skill tree. Each hero progresses individually and has a number of different arcs that can be upgraded. Thankfully if you feel that at any time your character isn’t performing the best that you think it can you are able to reclaim skill points and redistribute them into the skills that you believe will perform better. As I said previously the customization within the game is incredible.

From a technical perspective I really cannot fault the presentation. The graphics are perfect to capture the feel and aesthetic of the game that the developers had in mind for the game. They allow you the freedom that you desire to navigate throughout each map and add just the right amount of character to the game. The soundtrack and the sound are spotless as well. They aide the game to establish the mood and the ambiance that you would imagine from a horror themed tower defense game. It’s simply a superb game no matter which way you look at it.

Finally, there is an online multiplayer component to be added to the game which I am very much looking forward to. If anyone would like to play together then I am very much welcome to your invitation. There will be unique runes available to be won through the multiplayer mode. The multiplayer was not available at time of review but from the descriptor, below, it appears that it will be a combination of MOBA and tower defense. My only hope is that the game comes without latency issues as coming from Australia some online multiplayer games are impossible to play because of it.

My hope for this game is that when it is feature complete and released out of Early Access that the critics do not ignore the game. It deserves to have its time in the spotlight and I believe that many critics will be pleasantly surprised by how well-developed and polished this game actually is.

An easy recommendation to practically everyone. There is so much for everyone who likes playing video games to enjoy here even if you’re not traditionally a fan of tower defense games.

Product received for free

PROS:✔ The graphics are truly amazing!
Hero defence was clearly designed by someone who knows their stuff! The choice of colour, and combination of fog with a cartoon environment simply looks awesome! But you can see that from the trailer!

✔ The GUI is Beautiful!
It’s aesthetically pleasing, scales correctly, and just looks and feels great. It doesn’t need any explanation, you just know what everything does, the skill menu especially!

✔ The sounds are immersive!
Every action has a different sound, and it’s very noticeable! No corners were cut with the sound design!

✔ It offers a challenging experience!
Some games start slowly and build up the difficulty, but not in hero defence. Right away, you’re thrown in the deep end, with one moment of concentration loss losing you the game.

✔ A unique concept, with plenty to do!
It’s very interesting to play a tower defence where you can move your units!

✔ Simple and effective multiplayer!
The multiplayer definitely has potential. In short, it’s an extended singleplayer. Instead of playing by yourself, your friend’s singleplayer map is put next to yours so you can see how they’re doing. It has to be said though, there isn’t much time to watch them! It throws you into the end levels regardless of how far through the singleplayer you are.

✔ You can skip the tutorial!
I definitely saw an option to skip it! It’s such a burden when games don’t offer this functionality!




CONS:✖  It definitely gets repetitive.
You have to move your units back and forth a lot. Their range isn’t enough to kill everything from one spot, so you have to shift them along. Then, move them back to the spawn so there’s enough time to kill the next wave. Over and over again.

✖  The controls seem unnatural.
To move a unit, you left click it, and then right click the location you want them to move to. It took me a while to get the hang of this. There are key binds, but no option to change mouse control, unfortunately!

✖  You can’t select multiple units.
For the most part, you’ll want to move all your units together! But you can’t select multiple units, so you have to do it individually, which wastes a lot of precious time! Also, units push each other out the way to get past, but the unit that got pushed doesn’t move back after.

✖  The “Main Menu” is confusing
Instead of an option list, you’re presented with a burning city. However it’s not obvious as to what each building does. You just have to click them all until you find some gameplay! Floating text would be really helpful!

✖  The storyline felt forced.
This isn’t a game you play for the storyline, but even so. All the characters lack empathy or personality, and it all just feels slapped together. The protagonist told a guy who literally just lost his wife to a fire to “mourn her later”.

✖  Minor issues.
Enemies don’t move smoothly around corners, they snap quickly, which is very noticeable. The rune inventory is set. It looks like a standard inventory slot system, except you can’t put stuff where you want, everything has a default place. The heroes crossbow arrows come from the hero rather than the bow. Just little details like this that need fixing!

✖ One voice actor?
As awesome as some of the voices are, it honestly sounds like it was all recorded by one actor, using different inflections and pitch distortion software.



SUGGESTIONS:★ Collaboration multiplayer!
I really would love to experience some more engagement between you and the other player! Maybe a mode where both you and player 2 can move all the units together. Or to prevent exploitation from strangers, maybe you take control of 3 heroes, and they take the other 2.

★ More units!
The joy of tower defence is that you can build more and more units! But here you’ll always be stuck with the main characters. If you could rescue citizens for certain levels that you could also control, to help tackle each wave, that would definitely add some replayability!

★ Streamline the skill upgrades!
I enjoy doing things quickly. One major issue I had with the skill menu, is that you have to close each skill after upgrading it before selecting the next one. I’d love to be able to click the next skill immediately without needing to close the info!

★ Make the tutorial GUI clearer
The tutorial mainly consists of clicking on what the arrows tell you to click. However sometimes, it’s easy to miss where the arrows are on screen! Make the rest of the screen darker or something, just to highlight where I’m supposed to be looking!

A surprisingly pleasant take on tower defense games that I ended up enjoying  despute going in worrying about the potential for poor dev practices.

Hero Defense - Haunted Island is a tower defense style game where as opposed to building towers you control a hanful of heroes with thier own strengths that can be moved around the map in order to chase down the last few monsters. I enjoyed this feature since it made for less resetting every time  something got past me. All the usual suspects are here: Pure DPS, Slow effect, AEO, Mellee spawns in the middle of the enemy path, each of the heroes fill a basic purpose within the game that would otherwise be filled by a tower. Beyond that though if you ever played a tower defense game ever you can fill in the blanks on what happens during the defense portions of the game.

In the overworld there's a town on the outside of the level map where you can spend the gold and a secondary currency you earn and level up your heroes like you'd upgrade towers. I have to admit I initially thoughth that the secondary currency was going to be something you wither had to pay for or farm for endless periods of time to get, but I was proven wrong when a few levels in you can construct a bank that becomes your primary means of getting the blue currency by exchanging it for excess gold.

The game runs smoothly and I only had one crash shortly after my first boot of the game. Other than that initial crash it easily stays at 60 frames per second and hardly ever fluxuates for any reason.

If you're willing to turn the audio down and miss out on some corny voice acting and storytelling this makes for an excellent podcast game or something do do while you're waiting for a large download.

Hero Defense is a real gem.

The strong aspects of the game are its likeable heroes and rune system that always motivate you to come back for more.

My very subjective verdict:
Hero Defense is a tower defense game with 5 heroes that you can move on the map. The controls are spot on but I recommend to use the keyboard and learn the few shortcuts... this can save lives, especially in later levels.
You collect gold and runes in the game. Gold is needed to upgrade the buildings in the town in which you can level up your characters and weapons. You can also convert gold into diamonds in order to build so called hero shrines on the maps. Additionally you need diamonds to add rune slots to your weapons. In those weapon slots, you can place runes which are a lot of fun top experiment with. Each rune comes in 5 diferent tiers and there are 9 different runes per tier. In general, the metagame is very satisfying. You always enjoy to go back to the town and play around with your precious loot.
Graphics are very polished with some nice effects like fog, lightning and bloom but I wouldnt regard the visuals as the game's strong point but they definitely are nice too look at. I totally like the music and the sound fx as they do a perfect job in creating a very nice atmosphere that is second to noe when compared to other tower defense games.

If you like tower defense, this game is awesome!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hero Defense - Haunted Island is a tower defense game in early acces.
It has both single -and multiplayer modes.

Unlike other tower defense games where you place your defenses on the map,
Hero Defense - Haunted Island uses heroes which you can and have to move on the map
in order to succesfully defend yourself.

There are five different heroes, each with their own abilities.
Each hero is effective against certain mobs which is shown by the background color of the wave tiles.
There is a levelling system so you can upgrade your heroes' abilities and weapons.
In order to do this you need to succesfully defend waves and gather gold from mobs you defeat.

You can also boost your heroes during waves by collecting orbs from defeated mobs and charging them.
There are several charge levels and you can choose what aspect of your hero gets boosted by placing runes.
You can either find or buy runes.

Another way to boost your hero is using shrines. When you place your hero on a shrine he'll get a certain boost.
Some shrines are only usable by certain heroes and some are for all of them.

There are varied horror mobs to defeat such as vampires, zombies etc.
There are also champions which are tougher enemies and also bosses.

The singleplayer mode is a campaign with a simple story.
The multiplayer mode is like the campaign mode but against a human player.
Whoever defeats a wave first gets to punish the other player by sending extra mobs to him.

Hero Defense - Haunted Island is a fun game with decent graphics and audio.
It will require some grinding to max out all of your heroes but the game is fun enough to spend the time on it.

reviewText:
HD - Haunted Island is the story of a boy and his father... well, a vengeance-seeking vampire hunter after his demon-Dracula daddy! On the journey, our hunter Jack joins others to form the Fabulous Five - one being Sam whose voice files are unfortunately louder and pitched - so that they may rebuild the fallen town and slay the Count,

Yeah, a TD with plot. And voice acting! These devs know how to make me smile.

Graphics are simple and charming. I have nothing bad to say about them. Effects are great, and the game runs at a steady 30 FPS for me... which is lovely because I run most games at 15 FPS or lower!

Sounds! The music is subtle and it never gets annoying. Let me remind you that Steam Overlay has several options to allow you to play music as well as that every sound in HD can be muted! My only issue is how loud Sam's voice is in comparison to everyone else.

The gameplay is very interesting. Had you any experiance with Warcraft 3 mods, you may have played a similar map to what this game presents... I know I did, and I love it just as much now as I did back then. Basically, you will micromanage five Heros ( movable towers ) to eliminate enemies by using the best of the terrain available and shrines ( buff stations ). Battles will net you coin which you can use to purchase a variety of things in Town - the most important being Gems from the Bank. With those Gems,  you can expand a Hero's Inventory. Doing this will allow you to equip them with more Runes ( stat boosts ). One can also upgrade several buildings around town which in turn provide additional buffs and stat boosts. Enjoy the grind!

This is not pay to win. Yes, the word 'gems' has knifed our hearts out because of every flip-phone app out there... but let me reassure you: this is not a pay to win game. Gems can only be bought with gold, the game's in-game currency given out after battles.

Now, about Multiplayer... its play to win. It is very challenging to outperform a user who has endured more online matches than you. Not only would their Runes be better, but they would be more familiar to the maps. Try not to be frustrated if you get slammed hard in Multiplayer.

As of writing this - 6/3/16 - I hold the lowest Leaderboard position.

How do you avoid this? First of all, don't play against the same player over and over unless you're winning. Secondly, try to dedicate yourself to a Season of Multiplayer. Lastly, be mindful of the maps and how they synergize with Hero's and their runes. Don't be me on 6/3/16.

Rumor has it that co-op mode is coming! I truly hope to reach Top 3 this weekend because I would love to gift this game to my friends.

I do not regret anything about my purchase. The game is solid, the devs are friendly, and every day is Halloween!

Hello and welcome to my “Hero Defense - Haunted Island” review! This is a Horror/Comedy tower defense with RPG elements and a very simple storyline. The game overall isn’t too bad despite a few quality of life things they could add, such as a restart level feature, and mis-clicking/bombs seem to have problems, but other than that it is quite a great game!

Lets get on to the first part of my review:

Gameplay: The game itself is fun. I really love the horror-element to it and the fact that it is also a tower defense! There are a lot of good times to be had from the dialogue and very simple story. The game works out quite fine and you will enjoy leveling up your characters and seeing them progressively get stronger and stronger. This is absolutely crucial but the developers didn’t mention how important it is to convert gold to diamonds so you can level up your guys with them. Other than that, it is pretty solid! Good times will be had and it is not frustrating to play at all! So... 2.0/2.5

Controls: This is an easy criteria to get a high score for me. But.. This game has decent controls but not perfect. There are issues with bombs and they refuse to go off and you spam click and they for some reason will not blow up unless you put them in the perfect spot it seems. Also, there is no menu to seem to get out of the bomb screen that works properly. I got some damage done on myself because of this. Other than that the controls are not too bad. So for me... 1.5/2.5

Bugs/Glitches/Game-breaking stuff: Nothing too bad. Just issues with the bombs and the fact that you cannot click when they are equipped it seems. Also, sometimes the maps are awkwardly laid out and you have to run your crew into the corner of the map that is hard to click on. Not a whole lot of people complaining on the forums as well, so I would say they have success in this department! This gets a 2.0/2.5.

Value: This to me is the most important criteria when it comes to buying a game. For others, this may not matter so much. But, the basic calculation I always do is can I get 1$ per hour out of this game? Well. I do think so! Or close enough! The game is still in early access and you can replay the maps on hard if you’d like. It is 13 bucks at the moment so it should be easy enough to reach 13 hours on this game. Also, new content will be coming out apparently including MP. So, if you want to get a decent tower defense game I would pick this one up! Value: 2.0/2.5

Overall:  7.5/10.. Decent enough tower defense, but there is some shallowness to your defenses as you are only leveling up your heroes. Other tower defense games you do up your towers and witness them destroy the enemy. This one is not the case. Just heroes/their abilities and bombs. It is fun and you’ll have a good time, but don’t expect a perfect game! There is room for improvement but in order for that to happen I think a full re-haul on the whole game design would be fun. It is worth the 13 bucks for those of you who enjoy tower defenses.

reviewText:

IntroductionHero Defense - Haunted Island is a tower defence game mixed with some RPG elements which makes this game kind of unique and different from all the other Towere Defence games that are on steam at the moment. Especially as the game tries to tell a story instead of give you a bunch of levels to play as they get increasingly difficult as you get through more levels.

GameplayHero Defense - Haunted Island is a unique kind of tower defence, RPG game that tries to tell a story as you play through each of the levels of the game. As with all tower defence games, your goal is to build towers that you can control and a small amount of heroes in order to kill all the enemies before they get to whatever you are protecting. Each hero has their own strengths and weaknesses which balances the game out well, there are no heroes that are the strongest or the weakest. With the heroes that you aquire throughout the game, you will be able to send your hero to the enemies to fight them off if they got past your towered defences. This really makes the game more fun, which means less restarting if just one of the enemy gets past your towered defences. The overworld that you are in has a town on the outside of the map, here you can spend your gold and you are able to level up your heroes similar to how you would upgrade your defence towers that you have placed. Although you will have to spend a second kind of currency, which is a little harder to get than gold but doesn't turn into a microtransaction which is good. This is the RPG element to this game, that you can level up your heros and are able to move your heroes around and kill enemies if they get past your towered defences. The game also features some big bosses that you will have to defeat in order to win some of the levels that are in the game. Makes a nice change to have one massive boss rather than just more waves of enemies that get past your defences, which makes it rather nice and enjoyable to play. I would of liked to have the whole camera to be able to see the whole map, but for now you have to continously move the camera in order to see the map.

The graphics that accompany this game are very nicely presented and polished along with all the characters that are well presented and have nice animations when attacking enemies and such. There are some nice lighting effects of the game, and the shadows work well when your hero walks across the lighting. Its all very colourful and vibrant of colours that really make the game stand out from other games of the similar genre of game.

Pros+ Unique tower defence game with RPG elements
+ Beautiful graphics
+ Massive bosses
+ Achievements & Trading cards

Cons- Cant get the whole map on the screen

Result / Final thoughtsHero Defense - Haunted Island is a very fun and addictive Tower defence game with some RPG elements thrown in the mix as well. The game is well designed with it's level creation and the graphics and beautifully done. For a game that is in Early Access, it really seems to be holding well. The only thing that I didn't like was the camera, where you would have to continously move the camera to pick up items, and reposition your heroes. It would be nice to be able to get the whole map into one screen rather than moving around the camera all the time.

Rating: 9.5/10

You don't have the ability to scale to demands that you would expect in a TD, or the ability to fire off spells in rapid succession that you would expect in RPGs.
